title: Session 22: TBD
description: Looking for volunteers — a great chance to share your R expertise with the group!
contents: In this session, Jacob will share general security advice for software development.

title: Session 21: software security
description: Learn how to make your (R) code more secure
contents: New year, new software security. Start 2026 with smart habits to keep your (R) code safe and resilient.In this session, Jacob will share general security advice for software development.

title: Session 20: Christmas edition
description: Learn how to make your own Christmas card in R
contents:
In this session, you will learn how to create your own Christmas card in R using the ggplot2 package.
The content of this session is based on the information from this website.

title: Session 19: API's and live data
description: Learn how to connect to and interact with APIs using R.
contents: This session Bauke will present about API’s and live data.

title: Session 18: Q&A
description: An open session to ask R questions and share advice.
contents: If you have run into any issues or would like advice from your peers, you can bring them up during this meeting.

title: Summer break
description: Happy summer holidays!
contents: There will be no session due to the summer break. Happy summer everyone!

title: Session 17: Coding style
description: Learn about styling your code in R.
contents: In this session you will learn what coding style is, understand why consistent coding style is important, and get introduced to the tydiverse style guide.

title: Session 16: Efficient programming
description: Learn how to improve the efficiency of your R code.
contents:
In this session you will learn how to improve the effciency of your R code.
The session is be based on the book Efficient R programming.

title: Session 15: functions
description: Learn about functions in R.
contents:
During this session you will learn about functions in R.
The session is be based on chapter 6 of of the ‘Advanced R’ book in Chapman & Hall’s R Series.
source: https://adv-r.hadley.nz/functions.html

title: Session 14: Rshiny
description: Learn how to make an Rshiny app.
contents:
In this session we will learn how to generate apps/dashboards using Rshiny.
Material
The material will be available soon!

title: Session 13: making descriptive tables
description: Creating tables of descriptive statistics.
contents:
This week we will explore how to create ‘Table 1’ descriptive tables using an R script. In doing so, we will cover some new topics including loops and creating your own functions.
Material
The material for the session is available here.

title: Session 12: reporting regression results
description: Learn how to make tables and plots of regression results.
contents:
In this session we will learn how to automatically generate tidy tables from your regression results, and then visualize them using forest plots.
Material
The material for the session is available here.

title: Session 11: data visualisation
description: Learn about data visualisation using IMDB data on The Simpsons.
contents:
In this session we will use various data visualisation skills to explore the all-important question: has The Simpsons got worse over time?. We do this using data scraped from IMDB that has been made available on Kaggle.
Material
The material for the session is available here. This contains a complete prep script and the script used during the live demonstration itself.

title: Session 10: building websites
description: Learn how to build websites using the distill package.
contents:
In this session we will learn how to build a personal (academic) website using the distill package. The live demonstration will be loosely based on this material from Ariel Muldoon.
Material
The material for the session is available here. This contains the source material for the website we build during the session itself.

title: Session 9: GitHub
description: Learn how to use GitHub Desktop for version control.
contents:
In this session we will learn how to use GitHub Desktop for version control. Once you’ve mastered the basics of version control using GitHub Desktop, you will be better able to track changes to your own code, revert to old versions of your scripts, collaborate with others, and avoid the worry of losing your work.
You are welcome to sit back and listen, but if you’d like to actively follow along with the exercise during the workshop, please prepare the following steps beforehand:
Sign-up to GitHub.
Download GitHub Desktop.
Sign-in to your GitHub account within GitHub Desktop.
Download the example R project that we will work with. Unzip it and place the folder somewhere on your local machine.
Material
The material for the session is available here.

title: Session 8: unit tests
description: Learn how to run tests on your R code.
contents:
Thomas maintains an R package called splithalfr, which features some bespoke resampling methods (Pronk et al., 2021). To make sure everything in the package works correctly, he’s written a few unit tests. In this RUM-UMC session, Thomas will give a beginner-friendly introduction to unit testing in R, illustrated by the splithalfr package. Following that, we will briefly dip our toes into test automation via testthat
Material
The material for the session is available here.

title: Session 7: Quarto
description: Learn how to create reproducible slides and reports within R.
contents:
This session will introduce Quarto for publishing reproducible, high-quality documents, such as slides, articles and dashboards, from within R. You can take a look at some examples in the Quarto Gallery.
Material
The material for the session is available here.

title: Session 6: dates
description: Handling dates and visualisation using 112 meldingen.
contents:
In this session we will explore some data about emergency calls for service (e.g., ambulance) that were scraped from P2000 communication websites. The session will focus on handling dates (i.e., DD-MM-YYYY HMS) and visualisation.
Material
The material for the session is available here.

title: Session 5: reproducibility
description: Tips on ensuring your results can be reproduced.
contents:
Have you ever been sent an R script by a colleague and the code fails to run as promised? Or have you ever re-run one of your own scripts after a few weeks, and you get a new error or different results to last time? This has happened to pretty much every R user, but it is avoidable! In this session, we cover some top-tips for ensuring that the R scripts you write today will run again in the same way tomorrow (both for yourself, and colleagues).
Material
The material for the session is available here.

title: Summer break
description: We will take a short break over summer. Fijne vakantie!
contents: We will take a short break over summer. In the meantime, if you want to join the mailing list or suggest a topic for a future session, please get in touch!

title: Session 4: visualising your literature review
description: Visualise results from your literature review.
contents:
In this session, Ayu Dewi will give a live demonstration of how to create visualisations that summarise the results of your literature review.
Material
You can access all the material used in this workshop here. Even if you do not use GitHub, you can still download all this material by clicking on the green Code icon button, and then Download ZIP. Once you’ve unzipped that file, you are good to go.

title: Session 3: making maps
description: Introduction to mapping using sf.
contents:
In this session, we will give an introduction to geographic data and mapping using sf.
Material
You can view my full prep script here. The script used during the session itself is here.

title: Session 2: data visualisation
description: Introduction to data visualisation using ggplot2.
contents:
In this session, we will give an introduction to data visualisation using ggplot2 via a live coding demonstration.
Material
You can view my prep script here, and the script used in the demonstration itself is available here.

title: Session 1: tidytuesday
description: First session to kick-off the group & a short demonstration of tidytuesday.
contents:
In this session, we kick-off the R user meeting for Amsterdam UMC (RUM-UMC) with personal introductions, a conversation to find out people’s preferences for format and timings (e.g., frequency of meets, hybrid), followed by a brief demonstration of tidytuesday.
Material
You can find the script used during the session here.
